data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Add a launch file parameter for CI testing

We now use a launch file parameter to specify if we are running as part
of a CI pipeline and don't check the UDP connection if that's the case.

Also provide the `port` and `frame_id` as launch file parameters.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Add configure check for the UDP connection

The `configure` lifecycle transition now fails if there's no incoming
sensor data, i.e. if something's wrong with the connection.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Activate rolling in the CI

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Only publish with a non-zero subscription count

This keeps the driver's computations lean if nobody is listening.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Make `frame_id` a parameter

This allows users to set the `frame_id` of the published messages at
runtime via the node's parameter interfaces.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Use a unique pointer for the compound publisher

That's cleaner and makes sure that the compound publisher is valid after construction.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Adapt CI to newest changes

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Add integration test for the publishers

We add everything to our previous test file and change the name
accordingly.
Also rename the test methods to guarantee the order of definition inside the
test class. We need to call the `test_lifecycle` last, because that
finalizes the driver from which it cannot recover.

There seem to be workarounds for keeping the order of unittests, e.g.
[here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4095319) or
[here](https://codereview.stackexchange.com/questions/122532),
but that seems less intuitive and a little overkill for the little number
integrations tests that we add and maintain here.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Add a publisher for camera info

We use a separate class to encapsulate the different publishers so that
the lifecycle part stays nice and clean.

Only enqueue when receiving a complete blob udp

The *positive case first* is more readable.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Use the state's `id()` for checking the current state

That's a little cleaner than the string-based solution.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Publish only when new data arrives

This assures that we publish once a new data package is complete and can
be popped from the queue.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Fix lifecycle states and test on hardware

This now correctly performs all state transitions.
We reset the threaded communication upon `cleanup` so that we can go
through the complete lifecycle various times.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Include the base library

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Add producer-consumer data communication

We use Boost's single producer single consumer implementation that
nicely meets our requirements of non-blocking, thread-safe data
communication.

Add notes on how to configure and activate the node

That's just a reminder.
We'll improve the documentation later.

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message: Add minimal getting started note

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Deactivate `ament_lint_auto`

Clang format seems to clash with `uncrustify`.
Using `pre-commit` instead has the advantage of *commit-time* checks vs
*test-time* checks.

Let's add ament's other linters there later.

data.message: Clang-format previous files

data.author: Stefan Scherzinger
data.message:
Use the `ament_clang_format` config

That's the most common configuration.
The file is from
[here](https://github.com/ament/ament_lint/tree/rolling/ament_clang_format).

Either use `pre-commit run -a` before commiting or install it once
with `pre-commit install`.
